name: Mountain Lorikeet
description: It is one of the most vibrantly colored parrots, with a bright blue belly, blue head with dark red streaks, and a yellow-orange breast. It was previously considered a subspecies of the rainbow lorikeet.
spread_note: Eastern and southeastern Australia and adjacent islands
food_note: Nectar, pollen, flowers, small insects, soft fruits
image_alt: Mountain Lorikeet, photo: Martin Smrček, Prague Zoo
proportions: Length 26–30 cm; tail length 9.3–11.8 cm; wing length 13–17 cm; weight 75–157 g
attractions: While foraging, it climbs through tree canopies, often hanging upside down. During the day, it stays in small, noisy groups, while hundreds may gather at roosting sites at night, often resting on the ground. It was first brought to Europe in 1868.
breeding: According to preserved records, Prague Zoo kept these lorikeets in the 1950s, though the arrival of the very first individual is undocumented—we only know it died in 1952. Thereafter, lorikeets appeared in breeding programs with varying intervals, and from the mid-1980s, there are records of offspring.
